Input.threadtitle: Why so *little* haematite?
Input.posts:
The big splotch of haematite seen in Terra Merdiani certainly tells an interesting story, but why is it so rare on Mars? The only other places that apparently have large deposits are the Aram and Aureum Chaoses, and those are much smaller. There's iron oxide all over Mars, and in the Warm Wet model almost all of Mars would have seen some degree of surface water. So why do we only see a large deposit in this one area? John Grotzinger mentioned that the floor of Gale Crater has its iron in the form of magnetite instead, is there some sort of special chemistry that has to happen for iron to oxidise into haematite?

Or was there hematite lots of other places in which case where did it go and why? What could cause this, resurfacing due to erosion, impacts, vulcanism?

Input.threadtitle: Watt/hour really? Mistake in the course.
Input.posts:
WIKIPEDIA http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilowatt_hour 'Watts per hour (W/h) is a unit of a change of power per hour. It might be used to characterize the ramp-up behavior of power plants . For example, a power plant that reaches a power output of 1 MW from 0 MW in 15 minutes has a ramp-up rate of 4 MW/h. Hydroelectric power plants have a very high ramp-up rate, which makes them particularly useful in peak load and emergency situations. The proper use of terms such as watts per hour is uncommon, whereas misuse [12] may be widespread.' In 1.28, I am sorry to say that Dr Curiosity Rover misuses the unit W/h when he says the rover produces 100 W/h. Please amend the video!

What has gotten everyone's attention is the fact that a kilowatt is a rate of energy production per unit of time, and a kilowatt-hour is the total energy. Dividing that rate of energy production by a unit of time gets you nothing besides more Alice in Wonderland. Possibly, as Mr. Wong suggested, the writer meant that over a unit of time, the power supply is producing, on average over that unit of time, an average rate of energy production which may fluctuate, but on the average the power supply is producing that average rate of energy per unit of time. This gets, in my not so humble opinion, excessively complicated, due to a poor choice of words. If indeed, the writer means that the power supply is producing energy at a rate which may fluctuate but which over a unit of time, maintains an average rate of energy production, then I think it would be better to so specify. This maundering over the term 'watt per hour' is a good way to pass the lonely winter hours, but it is not even winter, and possibly is also not lonely, and may even be not an hour. I judge it appropriate to refer to that mistake which led to the loss of a Mars probe: just another example of the harm done by the United Statians (thank you, Ambrose Gwynne Bierce) in persisting in being the keepers of the sacred flame, pounding their feet in their yards. How many years, O Lord, and how many more Mars probes ?? Might make a nice refrain for a folk song ?

Input.threadtitle: Definition of Life
Input.posts:
In lecture 4.01 we are asked to give a definition of life. The script doesn't appear to accept any answer you give it, which is no doubt intentional, but I didn't discover that until I had made a couple of serious attempts at a definition. In particular, there were two words I was especially trying to get the script to swallow: Darwinian evolution. I was going to offer this definition: 'Life is a homeostatic chemical system which exhibits Darwinian evolution.' It turns out that NASA has a working definition of life: 'Life is a self-sustaining system capable of Darwinian evolution.” Close to mine -- 'self-sustaining' is more or less the same idea as 'homeostatic'. And I suppose I would surrender the word 'chemical' in my own definition if presented with nucleon-based life forms on the surface of a neutron star. The Darwinian evolution requirement packs in a lot: replication and inheritance, heritable variation, and fitness dependent on heritable variations as they interact with the environment. The self-sustaining or homeostasis requirement pack in metabolism and regulation. Lately, as we have learned that signaling processes are absolutely ubiquitous in life, it has become fashionable in biology to work signaling into the definition, as Wikipedia does: ' Life is a characteristic distinguishing objects having signaling and self-sustaining processes from those that do not.' Even bacteria send chemical signals to each other, and different biochemical pathways within cells communicate and coordinate their activities with signal molecules.

I'm slightly worried about tying the definition of life so strictly to Darwinian evolution. I think it's almost inevitable that any form of life will end up using the same sort of adaptation through selection, but I can't get rid of that 'almost'. It's very unlikely that other forms of life would develop different mechanisms of adaptation, but it's not inconceivable. In fact you could argue that for the past 100,000 years the human race has been evolving in a way that's markedly non-Darwinian. Life certainly requires the propagation of information over time, though, and the alteration of that information to enhance survivability. I would add something about energy gradients as well. Life is a process in which simple large energy gradients are transmuted into a complex array of smaller ones. Integrated with that concept is that of partitioning - creating barriers across which you can construct an energy gradient. This is the real reason that water is so important - it's not just a solvent, it's a solvent that allows partitioning.

Let's set aside the question of whether human cultural evolution is Darwinian. Life uses energy gradients ,and yes it does chop them up into convenient-sized pieces such as ATPs which are used to power chemical reaction via phosphorylation of enzymes. This chemistry is very precisely regulated. When you study the regulation systems you are definitely doing biology , not just chemical thermodynamics. The regulation systems involve chemicals signals and hence information. The enzymes that catalyze biochemical reactions are precision machines and also require information to make them. So regulatory information is central in biology. And what process makes that regulatory information? Darwinian evolution. That's why I think it is essential. The ingredients for making nucleic acids such as RNA are apparently common in interstellar space, and it now looks like earlier concerns about abiosynthesis of RNA and instability of RNA can be addressed. E.g. RNA is quite stable in double helix form, RNA has catalytic ability (a ribozyme) and can play the role of enzymes before translation evolves. So a molecular basis for information and catalysis is readily available on the early Earth. Darwinian evolution is launched the first time you have an RNA sequence with ribozymal activity. It might, for example, have attached a phosphate group to the end of a (primordial) fatty acid chain, making a phospholipid. Now you have functional information which can be selected for, in a Darwinian way, as cells with fatty acid membranes doped with phospholipids are better able to grab fatty acid chains away from other cells.

Okay, let's give a refresher about Evolution. The process by which organisms change through time relies on 4 mechanisms: Mutation, Migration, Drift and Selection. The assumptions necessary for these mechanisms to take place are the organism's ability to carry -and transfer- information and variability of information among different organisms. The success of an organism is defined by the result of the interactions between said organism and its environment. The ability to grow, reproduce,and eventually manipulate the environment are ultimately consequences of those mechanisms. And (for Pr. Brown) plants DO manipulate their environment in absolutely awesome ways. Defining Life as anything that follows Evolution is fine but possibly a bit too wide a definition. e.g.: Languages follow these rules (see memetic). But maybe it's fair enough as long as we don't have a second Tree of Life (A martian one?) for comparison. In my opinion, it does not make sense to add 'self-sustaining' to the definition of a living organism for two obvious reasons: death exists; most organisms rely on interactions (like eating) to keep on living. Life as a whole, however, is an open self-sustaining system. As in, death doesn't matter as other living things will take care of the dead ones and positive feedbacks loops are created through the interactions of all living things with each other (See Dyke 2013, http://www.ploscompbiol.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pcbi.1003050 ). In lecture 4.01 we are asked to give a definition of life. The script doesn't appear to accept any answer you give it, which is no doubt intentional, but I didn't discover that until I had made a couple of serious attempts at a definition. In particular, there were two words I was especially trying to get the script to swallow: Darwinian evolution. I was going to offer this definition: 'Life is a homeostatic chemical system which exhibits Darwinian evolution.' It turns out that NASA has a working definition of life: 'Life is a self-sustaining system capable of Darwinian evolution.” Close to mine -- 'self-sustaining' is more or less the same idea as 'homeostatic'. And I suppose I would surrender the word 'chemical' in my own definition if presented with nucleon-based life forms on the surface of a neutron star. The Darwinian evolution requirement packs in a lot: replication and inheritance, heritable variation, and fitness dependent on heritable variations as they interact with the environment. The self-sustaining or homeostasis requirement pack in metabolism and regulation. Lately, as we have learned that signaling processes are absolutely ubiquitous in life, it has become fashionable in biology to work signaling into the definition, as Wikipedia does: ' Life is a characteristic distinguishing objects having signaling and self-sustaining processes from those that do not.' Even bacteria send chemical signals to each other, and different biochemical pathways within cells communicate and coordinate their activities with signal molecules.
